metadata.title: Nonlinear buckling of functionally graded nano-/ micro-scaled porous beams

sections.text: Functionally graded materials (FGMs) and porous materials are two special and new branches of materials with unique applications and properties. Emerging nano-/micro-science is growing every day and for this purpose, FGMs and porous materials can be used in smallscale systems. In this study, the nonlinear buckling characteristics of functionally graded nano-/micro-beams which are made of porous materials are studied based on Euler-Bernoulli beam theory for the first time. Considering the von Kármán geometric nonlinearity, governing equations of nano-beam are derived using Eringen’s nonlocal theory and the modified couple stress theory is utilized to obtain the governing equations of microbeam. The generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) is used along with the iteration technique to obtain the nonlinear results. The results are depicted to show the effects of different parameters on the nonlinear buckling behavior of the functionally graded (FG) porous micro-/nano-beams for clamped boundary condition.

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Nonlinear Buckling; Functionally graded; Porous materials; Eringen’s theory; Modified couple stress theory; GDQM.
1. Introduction
In recent decade, by development of new small-scaled technologies, the application and usages of micro- and nano-structures are increasing continuously. Hence, it is required to analyze the different behaviors of these new structures before the manufacturing. For this purpose, many scientists have devoted their time to study micro- and nanostructures and buckling and dynamic analysis are a part of these studies. Many researches have been conducted on the buckling, and vibration behavior of micro- and nano-plates, Farajpour et. al [1], Narendar [2], Jamalpoor and Hosseini [3], Farahmand et. al [4], Farokhi and Ghayesh [5], Wang et. al [6], Pradhan and Phadikar [7], Murmu and Pradhan [8], micro- and nano-shells [9-13] and micro/nanotubes [14-17]. Arefi and Zenkour [18] studied the free vibration and bending of a sandwich microbeam considering piezo-magnetic layers as sensor and actuator. Besides, the natural frequencies of a thermoelastic microbeam resonator was also studied by Zenkour [19]. Functionally graded materials (FGMs) were introduced in 1984 as a new branch of materials which have different material composition along to an axis (x, y or z) and have many applications [20-22]. Accordingly, many scientists focused their studies to define the different behaviors of structures made of FGMs [23-25]. Recently, Şimşek [26] studied the buckling of beams using two-dimensional FGMs. Kandasamy et. al [27] analyzed the free vibration and thermal buckling of moderately thick FGM plates, cylindrical panels and shells. Şimşek and Yurtcu [28] studied the static bending and buckling of a FG nanobeam. Zhang et. al [29] examined the thermal buckling of FG plates were studied. Şimşek and Reddy [30] introduced a unified higher order beam theory for studying the buckling of FG microbeam embedded in elastic Pasternak medium. Akgöz and Civalek [31] studied the thermomechanical size-dependent buckling FG microbeams. Ansari et. al [32] studied the bending, buckling and free vibration of Timoshenko FG microbeams. Nejad et. al [33] examined the buckling analysis of the nano-size beams made of two-directional FGM. Duc et. al [34] studied the nonlinear buckling and post-buckling of thin annular spherical FG shells subjected to mechanical load and resting on Winkler-Pasternak type elastic foundations. Akgöz and Civalek [35] studied a shear deformation beam model and new shear correction factors for nonhomogeneous microbeams. Ebrahimi and Dashti [36] studied the free vibration characteristics of a rotating double tapered FG beam. Thermo-mechanical vibration of FG nanobeams and FG beams are respectively studied by Ebrahimi and Salari [37] and Ebrahimi and Jafari [38]. Duc et. al [39] studied the nonlinear dynamic response and vibration of
imperfect eccentrically stiffness functionally graded elliptical cylindrical shells on elastic foundations. There have been other studies on FGM structures as well such as [40-43]. In addition to the functionally graded, the materials with porous medium are another unique kind of material with applications from micro and nanoscience and energy storage to medical diagnosis [44-47]. Emerging applications of porous materials have led to many conducted researches regarding the mechanical behavior of these materials. Khorshidvand et. al [48] studied the buckling of a solid circular porous plate bounded with piezoelectric sensor– actuator patches. Cheng and Xu [49] studied the out-of-plane buckling of thin bending plates for a given amount of material. Shan et. al [50] used numerical and experimental approaches to study the effects of pore shape and lattice pattern on the mechanical behavior of the structures. Magnucka-Blandzi [51] studied the buckling and deflection of a circular porous plate. The rising micro- and nano-technology desires new types of materials and for this purpose, FGMs and porous materials are two kinds of applicable materials in small scaled structures. Thus, the behavior of these materials is needed to be known in micro- and nano-size systems. Shafiei et. al [52] studied the size dependent nonlinear vibration behavior of imperfect FG microbeams. Ghadiri and SafarPour [53] studied the free vibration of FG porous cylindrical microshell under thermal effects. Zhang [54] studied thermal post-buckling and nonlinear vibration behaviors of FGM beams and also FGM rectangular plates Zhang and Zhou [55]. Also, nonlinear bending analysis of FGM beams and also modeling of rectangular FGM plates considering neutral surface effects are performed by Zhang [56] and Zhang [57], respectively. Most recently, Shafiei and Kazemi [58] studied the buckling of twodimensional functionally graded tapered Euler–Bernoulli nano and micro beams made of porous materials. Chen et. al [59] studied the elastic buckling and static bending analysis of shear deformable FG porous Timoshenko beams. Şimşek and Aydın [60] static bending and forced vibration of an imperfect FG microplate carrying a moving load are studied. It can be observed that the buckling analysis of FG porous micro- and nano-beams has not been studied yet. For this purpose, this study is focused on the nonlinear buckling behavior of functionally graded micro- and nano-beams made of porous material. The problem is studied using the nonlocal Eringen’s theory in the nanoscale and the modified couple stress theory for the micro-scale analysis. The solution procedure is on the basis of the generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) and also the iteration technique for obtaining the nonlinear results. Finally, the parametric study is served to show the effects of porosity, FG index, nonlinearity, small scale effects, etc., on the nonlinear buckling behavior of FG porous micro-
and nano-beams.
2. Problem and formulation
A functionally graded beam is considered with length of ‘L’, width ‘b’ and height ‘h’ which are located on x, y and z directions, respectively as shown in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1. Schematic of the FG nanobeam
2.1.Functionally graded material
The concerned FG micro- and nano-beams are composed of metal and ceramic with varying material volume composition and so, varying physical and mechanical properties of through the thickness (Fig. 1). The property variation is defined by the power law function as:

According to Eqs. (1) and (2) the material of the bottom surface, (z = -h/2) and the top (z = h/2) of the FG beams are pure metal and pure ceramic, respectively and the physical and mechanical properties of the FG beam can be defined as a function of ceramic and metal volume fractions as below:
( )c c m mF(z) V (z) F F F= − + (3)
In Eq. (3), F(z) defines the properties (either physical or mechanical) of the beam at a specific point (z). Also Fc and Fm are variables of physical and mechanical properties of pure ceramic and metal, respectively.
2.2. Porous structures
Porosity distributions can be different, and two types of them are shown in Fig. 2. According to Eqs.(1)-(3) and the shown porosity distribution types, [61], the physical and mechanical properties of the FG porous micro and nanobeams can be defined as below: Porous type I:

2.3.Mathematical modeling
2.3.1. Nonlocal theory
The Eringen’s nonlocal elasticity theory says that the stress at a point depends on a region around that point [62]. Through this assumption, the nonlocal elasticity theory puts the long range interaction between the points in a model into consideration. As for this reasons, the nonlocal elasticity theory is used in this paper to derive the governing equation of the nanobeam, and also has been used many times to study the behavior of nanostructures [63,
64]. According to Euler-Bernoulli beam theory, and using the nonlocal theory, the general equation of nonlinear buckling of FG Euler nanobeam can be written as [24, 65]:

2.3.2. Modified couple stress theory
The micro-size beam is studied using the modified couple stress theory which was first proposed by Toupin [66] and Mindlin and Tiersten [67] and at first had two sized parameters. After that, Yang et. al [68] modified the proposed couple stress theory to a theory which used one size parameter. Since then, the modified couple stress theory, has been used many times to study the behavior of microstructures [69-73]. The general nonlinear equation of vibration of 2D-FG Euler-Bernoulli microbeam is based on the modified couple stress theory is written as [24]:

4. Numerical result
The explained solving approach is applied to derive the nonlinear buckling load for classic beam, microbeam and nanobeam. The results are depicted for different values of FG index (n), porosity volume fraction (α), nonlinear amplitude (Amp), nonlocal value (µ) and small scale parameter (l0) to illustrate the effect of these parameters on the buckling characteristics of FG porous classic beam, microbeam and nanobeam. It should be noted that all the results are derived when the length to height ratio is L/h=40. For showing the figures in understandable and clear shapes, the normalized critical buckling load (NCBL) is defined as bellow:
( ) Nonlinearbucklingof microornanobeam

Fig. 4 shows the normalized critical buckling load of two types of porous micro/nanobeams for different values of FG index, porosity volume fraction (α), when µ=l0=0.2. Comparing Fig. 4 (a) and (b), respectively with Fig. 4 (c) and (d) shows that the critical buckling load of type II is higher than that of type I. The reason is that the stiffness of type I porosity is lower than the stiffness of type II. Young's modulus of FG porous I and II materials is given in Fig. 5 for different values of FG power index and porosity distribution factor. It is observed that increment of α and n decreases Young's modulus and thus decreases the stiffness of the beam. In addition, comparing Fig. 4 (a) and (c), respectively with Fig. 4 (b) and (d) illustrates that the critical buckling load of microbeams is higher than nano-size beams. Besides, as increasing the FG power index of micro/nanobeams decreases the stiffness, it leads to the decrement of the critical buckling load. It can also be observed in Fig. 4 that increasing the porosity volume fraction (α), decreases the critical buckling load and the effect of α on microbeams is higher than nanobeams and also the effect of α on type I porosity is more than type II.
Fig. 4. Normalized critical buckling load of porous micro (b,d) and nanobeams (a,c) versus FG power index when Amp=2 and L/h=40.

the nonlinear amplitude for different values of nonlocal parameter (µ), FG power index (n) and porosity volume fraction (α). It is obvious in Fig. 6 that the nonlocal parameter decreases the critical buckling load since the nonlocal parameter decreases the stiffness. Also, as the nonlinearity increases the stiffness of nanobeam, the critical buckling load increases with the nonlinear amplitude. Same as in Fig. 4 it is seen in Fig. 6 that the FG power index and α decrease the critical buckling load.
Fig. 6. Normalized critical buckling load (NCBL) of type I CC nanobeam versus the nonlinear amplitude when L/h=40.
Fig. 7 shows the normalized critical buckling load of type I clamped-clamped microbeam versus the nonlinear amplitude for different values of small scale parameter (l0), FG power index (n) and porosity volume fraction (α). It is seen in Fig. 7 that unlike nanobeams, the small scale parameter increases the critical buckling load of microbeams which is because the small scale parameter in the modified couple stress theory increases the stiffness of the microbeam. On the other hand, similar to nanobeam, the nonlinear effect increases the stiffness of the microbeam and so, the critical buckling load of microbeam increases with the nonlinear amplitude. As it was seen in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, the FG power index and α decrease

the critical buckling load.
The critical buckling load, of clamped (cc) local, micro and nanobeams is depicted in Table. 4 for different values of nonlinearity (Amp), FG power index (n), small scale parameter (l0) and nonlocal parameter (µ). It is seen that increasing the nonlinear amplitude increases the critical buckling load of clamped beams while the FG power index decreases the value of critical buckling load. It should be noted that, increasing the small scale parameter in the modified couple stress theory (l0) increases the stiffness and the critical buckling load while increasing the nonlocal value (µ) has different effect and decreases the
. In another way, it can be said that by decreasing the small scale effect, the critical
buckling load ( ) of micro and nanobeams converge to the critical buckling load of local beam.

5. Conclusion
This paper was aimed to present a study on the nonlinear buckling behavior of porous microand nanobeams made of functionally graded materials (FGMs). The governing equations were developed using the Eringen’s nonlocal elasticity theory for nanobeam and modified couple stress theory for microbeam. The generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) is utilized to derive the answers and the iteration technique is employed to obtain the nonlinear results considering the clamped (CC) boundary condition. Finally, parametric studies were presented to show the effects of nonlinearity, porosity, small scale parameters and FG index on the nonlinear buckling behavior of the FG porous nano- and micro-size
beams. Here, the most important results are:
• The nonlinear buckling load (NCr) and normalized critical buckling load (NCBL)
increase with the nonlinear amplitude.
• The FG power index (n) and the porosity volume fraction (α) decrease the nonlinear
buckling load (NCr) and normalized buckling load (NCBL), as they decrease the stiffness. • The normalized critical buckling load (NCBL) of type II porous beams is higher than
type I because the stiffness of type II is more than that of type I.
• The nonlinear buckling loads of local beam are higher than nanobeams and lower than
microbeams. In fact, by decreasing the small scale effect, the critical buckling load of micro and nanobeams converge to the critical buckling load of local beam.
• Increasing the FG power index (n) and the porosity volume fraction (α), decrease the
effects of nonlinearity and small scale on the micro and nanobeams.

metadata.abstractText: Functionally graded materials (FGMs) and porous materials are two special and new branches of materials with unique applications and properties. Emerging nano-/micro-science is growing every day and for this purpose, FGMs and porous materials can be used in smallscale systems. In this study, the nonlinear buckling characteristics of functionally graded nano-/micro-beams which are made of porous materials are studied based on Euler-Bernoulli beam theory for the first time. Considering the von Kármán geometric nonlinearity, governing equations of nano-beam are derived using Eringen’s nonlocal theory and the modified couple stress theory is utilized to obtain the governing equations of microbeam. The generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) is used along with the iteration technique to obtain the nonlinear results. The results are depicted to show the effects of different parameters on the nonlinear buckling behavior of the functionally graded (FG) porous micro-/nano-beams for clamped boundary condition.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
